commentBody: I can't help but try to negotiate lower prices for some purchases by offering cash. Someone is paying a % of that sale to the credit card companies: if I use credit, I'll get a little something back, the seller will pay a little something.  But offering cash often provides a direct discount. Not for a coffee -- but for, say,  two new crowns at the dentist? That's a great place to haggle - another old fashioned New York custom.

This is digital age. As such majority love to make payment through cards either online or in person. However there are certain drawbacks in this system since not everyone is in a position to accept cards and as such cash payment is required for certain day to day purchases.

There are certain drawbacks with the cash payment since there is bound to be fear of losing the money. However there is no guarantee that we don’t lose money either if paid through credit cards since there are plenty of means to steal our money by fraudulent acts.

The biggest advantage with the cash payment is that we only buy goods within the limits of cash on hand and simply not exceed it. In the case of credit card, there is every possibility of buying goods out of temptation rather than the exact need. As such we end up paying much more than what is necessary considering the eventual interest to be paid over a period of time since it’s not our money but borrowed.
Sometimes the toughest decision is when I step to the register to pay and I have enough cash sitting right next to the credit card inside of my wallet.
My local barber doesn't take any form of payment except cash.  There's no sign that states that fact but everyone seems to manage it just fine.

commentBody: Who fails to pay with some sort of app is interfering with the economic destruction of the middle class.

When everyone prefers or seems to prefer electronic payment, using cash isn't old-fashioned, it's subversive.
Embrace being a mysterious factor in marketing analysis while you can!
My husband and I stopped by a bakery cafe recently intending to purchased a loaf of artisan bread when the attendant explained they don't take cash. So we didn't buy bread.

We live fairly well. Pay utilities through the bank in the village, but for all other purchases we find it easier and more budget friendly to pay with cash. No-one overspends and the smaller shops appreciate it as they do not have to pay bank fees as with a charge card.

There are some establishment in Canada that offer betweena 3 to 5% discount if you pay in cash. We are used to asking for a cash discount. You still have to pay the tax on items, but bank fees are eliminated. Win-win for all.

We also find it faster to pay with cash. No trinkets to fiddle with.

Most often, when I encounter celebrities, if I can, I act as if I don’t know who they are.  That way I can truly get a sense of how they really are.  I had a lovely encounter with a well-known actress at Marshall’s of all places.  She saw the towels I was holding in the checkout line, complimented me on them, asked if she could feel them (like buttah, she joked) and then she ran to get herself some, following my directions.  At a social function, I met someone well-known in the media and we talked about what we watch on tv when we’re tired of watching Trump news.  I never let on I knew who she was.  

This way, they get a break from someone’s gushing and I get a nice experience to think about fondly.  Win, win.
I pay with credit card in restaurants but, especially in less expensive places, always tip in cash. Otherwise, I'm never sure how much my server really gets.

Not even 10 years ago, I used to get my daily coffee at a shop below my apartment on Broadway in the West 90s. It was $2.10 and so every day I brought a dime. And also that store is now gone and has been 2 or 3 things since, along with most of the other shops on the block.

I pay most things with a credit card because I get between 1 and 5% cash back. But for small purchases such around the $2 to $6 range, I pay with cash, because I find it unfair--especially for small retailers--to make the merchant pay 2% in credit card processing fees.

commentBody: I missed my mother’s 90th birthday celebration this year, another sign of my surrender to family history I could not change. I visited her privately, which was quite meaningful, but it wasn’t the same as celebrating her among gathered family, as she'd asked of me. A little more than one month later, mom passed quietly, peacefully, in her sleep. I hadn't fully understood what it would mean for that to have been my last visit with mom, or how I'd feel long afterwards having not accepted what would be her last invitation of me. Sarah’s words, “I wish I’d asked her,” remind me so much of my relationship with mom. Those aren't easy feeling. Thank you for that.

Mike Malsbury’s evocation of Waverly Place instantly brought to mind the Waverly Consort, my favorite early music ensemble for more than fifty years, which its founders, the late Michael Jaffee and his wife Kay, created in the early 1960s when they were living in the Village. Like many other devoted annual attendees, I particularly loved the ensemble’s annual December concert recounting the Christmas Story as Told Through the Music of the Middle Ages, performed in the perfect setting of the Fuentiduena Chapel at The Cloisters. Brilliantly designed to never have a pause long enough to invite applause, the program was always spellbinding from first note to
last. I will always treasure the memory of that hauntingly beautiful program and of the wonderful Waverly Consort that conceived and performed it.

In the summer of 76 I worked at the UPS hub on W43rd. UPS divided Manhattan into 5 zones and a condition of employment was knowing the zone for every address on the entire island. Having failed miserably on the first attempt, mostly in zones 1 and 5, the named streets in lower and upper Manhattan, I made a flash card for every address with the zone on the back. There were a few streets that kept stumping me so instead of putting that card in the back of the stack, I would place it some where in the middle so it would come up again sooner.

After much flashing I passed on the second try with only 1 wrong answer.

The Diary entry titled “Studious” sparked a memory for me. 

My sister worked as a waitress in a fancy restaurant back in the early 1970s. She always enjoyed taking drink orders from the diners and giving them to the bartender. On slow nights, she would watch the bartender mix the drinks. 

One night the bartender called in sick. The manager wondered what to do! My sister said, “I can make most of the drinks. I’ve watched the bartender do it.”  

She did it that night, and she realized that she’d rather be a bartender than a waitress. She went to Bartenders School, passed the exam, and became a licensed bartender. 

I stopped by her restaurant a few times, and I can attest that she made a mean martini. :-)

Cash and Carry is very interesting to read. In India, plenty of transactions are still done in cash even though many transactions have become online thanks to credit and debit cards. In the case of cash transactions, change in minor denominations is a huge problem both for the seller and for the buyer in India even same as mentioned in this story. 

It’s the cents, dimes and quarter that create plenty of problems most of the time and not dollars.

It’s interesting to learn that knowledge of French is required for passing a bartender examination in America. However the guessing game is interesting in the story Studious.

Her Numbers story has made me smile. Even in this story the guessing game by the writer is quite interesting. The reason for my smile is that my wife is fond of buying lottery tickets whenever we lived and or toured America limited to certain amount. During our recent trip to Ann Arbor, MI she used to buy lottery tickets not exceeding $ 5 to 6 per day once in three days on our walking trips. She always used to buy some specific numbered lottery tickets that need scratching. Most of the time she used to lose. However one day she happened to win $ 50. As such she decided to spend all the $ 50 by way of purchase of lottery tickets before we left America in the third week of September and she more or less succeeded in losing that amount rather happily.

Scooter Spill is interesting to read too. The writer must have felt happy on account of unexpected meeting.
